title: Worldwise: High-End Designer Joyce Wang’s Favorite Things
text:
Text size

Ever since she was a child, Joyce Wang wanted to be a designer. Today, Wang commands a design firm, Joyce Wang Studio, behind some of the most stunning and iconic luxury interiors in the world: a renovation of London’s Mandarin Oriental (recently reopened after a fire); Ichu, famed Peruvian chef Virgilio Martinez's new restaurant in Hong Kong; Jin Gui, a high-end restaurant in Hamburg; the Landmark Mandarin Oriental in Hong Kong; and many more. Wang says she approaches interior design like a filmmaker: incorporating elements of suspense, building character, monitoring flow.

Splitting her time between London and Hong Kong, where she was raised, Wang, who is in her mid-thirties, has developed a reputation, in a relatively short period of time, as an artistic visionary. Her projects, harmonious, expansive designs with lots of marble, wood, and stone, all bear the mark of a distinct, artistic mind.

We reached out to Wang to hear about some of her favorite things around the world.

My favorite neighborhood in the world is… a lesser known area between Bayswater and Marylebone [in London] called Connaught Village. The village is lined with boutique-style artisanal shops. Some of my favorites include Buchanon’s, the local cheesemonger, MarkusCo ffee–it’s where all the bobbies guarding Tony Blair’s house get their coffees; and Abasto, an Argentine grocery. It gets festive in the village with special events like opera in the Italian restaurant over Christmas.

Courtesy Joyce Wang

The one thing in my kitchen I can’t live without is… my olive wood butter knife–it has the right amount of flex to scrape every bit of Nutella from the jar and is at room temperature when I put it in my mouth.

If I were to buy a piece of art, it would be by… anything by George Condo. He taught me art at Harvard when I was still studying and he was a struggling artist!

The best book I’ve read in the last year is… Educated, by Tara Westover. She writes poetically about my favorite part of the U.S., Idaho. The memoir makes me appreciate just how different people’s lives can be and how all the same there’s a will to live and succeed, no matter the circumstance.

A passion of mine that few people know about is… Design Trust. I’ve been contributing auction items to the Design Trust in Hong Kong annually in support of local young designers as well as established designers who do meaningful work.

The one trip I’ve taken that I would love to do again… Zion National Park, Utah. I’ve been there four times now and it’s a place that I’ll always go back to. The landscape is magical and the hikes dramatic, you feel the weight of time there. It’s the kind of landscape that conjures up epic scenes of dinosaurs.

The next destination on my travel itinerary is… going back to Melbourne for the second time. I had an amazing first trip there: the food, the art, the design, the host I had, and the people I met. I loved the botanical gardens and all the creative ideas the city has with which to inspire its population. I’m also going to Kyoto for our annual team trip later this year. We will be sourcing antiques for an ongoing Japanese residential project and staying in a Machiya House by the canal together.

The thing that gets me up in the morning is… working alongside my team and knowing that the best ideas always come from all of us working together.

The restaurant in my hometown that I love to take a visitor is… Mott 32, because it represents Hong Kong and I designed it with my studio. Most importantly, the food is excellent.

If I could have a drink with anybody, anywhere, it would be… I’d love a mulled wine, après ski preferably, with my family!
description: The Hong Kong-raised design star loves London’s Connaught Village, an olive wood butter knife, art by George Condo, and more
